setup.question: How did Retief beat Hoshick?
answers: He twisted his tentacles and injured him
He used what he learned from capturing the flap-jack

Text.text: Flap-Jack sounds stupid, even by pulp sci fi standards, so vaguely leaning A. Wondering why Retief would capture a pancake.
"Flap-jack" is the colloquial term for the Jaq, a lifeform that Terrestrials ran into on planet Adobe. The flap-jacks are
and
, hence the name. At their edges they have

which used for manipulation.

These are sensitive organs. Negotiating their fight's rules, Retief suggests
, allowing
and more. Concerned about the advantage the rules give Retief, Hoshick asks:
Retief agrees, but he ends up doing it anyway, as:
. It's not explicitly stated, but the "fringe rippling" is best understood as being due to tentacle twisting.

Retief and Hoshick both agree to no tentacle twisting, this should make you seriously doubtful of any analysis A makes where they extrapolate that Retief uses tentacle twisting. 

Flap-jack is the species which Hoshick belongs to, which has a unique biology that Retief exploits.

I can provide more evidence proving how effective this knowledge is. In an earlier confrontation, Retief gets into a fight with a Flap-jack, and his thumb accidentally slips into an orifice, showing him the weakness.

A: Can you provide a quote between 5869 and 6191 that Retief does it anyways.
B: Can you provide any evidence that 1) the flap-jack was captured 2) that Retief learned something from it and 3) that that information was used in some capacity. I'm not getting any evidence about him learning anything from you.

Unfortunately I can't provide a direct quote. The text mostly describes Retief gouging the flap-jack's eye, which is the "sensitive orifice" referred to in B's quote. This is the strategy that he uses to distract and discombobulate Hoshick so he can twist his tentacles without Hoshick catching on to his abuse of the rules. And he gets away with it, with Hoshick unwilling to call him out on any suspected foul play:

On the other hand, Retief is an experienced diplomat and strong fighter. Eye-gouging was not a lesson from his earlier encounter with a flap-jack, it's simply an effective technique Retief deployed in that context. B won't be able to show that this was newly learned.
Earlier in the story, Retief has an encounter with another Flap-jack. He nearly loses to it in a fight, but
This is done accidentally, and Retief remembers this information in his fight with Hoshick. Retief tells the fj

. 

You should be seriously skeptical of A who admits that there is no evidence proving that tentacles are twisting. A concedes that Retief gouges the eye, which is how he beats Hoshick. He doesn't do this so he can twist the tentacles, the quote between Retief gouging and Hoshick going limp just details how Retief is

I'm going to go one more round. I like the burden B puts on A.
A) Rippling seems different than twisting. Fringe also seems different than a tentacle. This is the last chance to provide any additional direct quotations that a tentacle was twisted. If you can expand upon  why "fringe rippling" is understood to be tentacle twisting (ie is the term used earlier), that would suffice.

B) Can you expand a bit more on the earlier fight with the flap-jack?
The fringe is just the flap-jack's edge, where tentacles come out from. "Rippling" is often used to describe how they move, for example:
The most explicit quote is when Retief is searching on Hoshick with his hands:
. The flap-jacks are totally flat (e.g.,
); the only hand-holds are tentacles. The "

" is clarifying that he's still gouging the eye while tentacle-twisting.

All B has shown is Retief gouged the earlier flap-jack's orifice. Again, Retief didn't learn this technique here, and B can't show evidence that he did.
After finding the orifice and getting the upper hand in the earlier battle, Retief says

Retief learns that eye-gouging, the main strategy he used in the first fight, is effective against other flap-jacks, which he uses later on.

On A: Rippling is the movement of the tentacles, but this has no direct relation to tentacle TWISTING. A's evidence doesn't mention fringe rippling or even rippling again, and as always, no direct mention of tentacle twisting. The total lack of any evidence about tentacle twisting happening from both sides should frame the debate, since A is really semantic heavy.
I am convinced that Retief learned something with a previous encounter with a flap-jack. A doesn't specifically address twisting which seems like a different action.

Both seem fairly odd. I'd need to learn what type of creatures both of them are. They seem like humanoid names meaning A would be unlikely but that isn't necessarily the case. "Of the red" in the title makes me think the theme will be something pirate related, so B would seem likely as capturing and whatnot is what pirates do.

Ok so from here I've learned that Hoshick is a creature that does have tentacles, meaning it's possible for them to be twisted.

Both sides at the very least agree that R and H /agreed/ to no tentacle twisting, but there is no conclusive evidence as to what /really/ happened, but I'm still leaning towards A.

Additionally, B never provides any offense, what /did/ R learn from capturing flap-jacks? Has he captured any flap-jacks previously?

Ok this definitely changes things. B has shown me that R /has/ fought flap-jacks before and that he learned of a particular weakness, the orifice, which is again what he used vs H. Debater A also seems to have run out of juice, and is just making a bunch of conjectures which leads me to believe B is true, and thus I end the debate.

answers.reason for outcome: B could provide the key ev that I wanted and A ran out of steam.

There was just no evidence for tentacle-twisting actually happening, and the debate was allowed to go on long enough for this to be exposed. On the other hand, B with 2 or 3 turns was able to justify their full story, even as it was a little bit complex.
